conclusion: The problem involves determining if the displacements of cars A and B are the same based on their velocity-time graphs from t=0 to t=t₁.

The first image shows velocity-time graphs for two cars (A and B). Car A starts at velocity v₁ and increases to v₂, while Car B starts at v₂ and decreases to v₁. Both cars travel in the same direction.
The second image shows the same velocity-time graphs with red shading highlighting the areas under the curves.
In a velocity-time graph, the displacement of an object during a time interval equals the area under the velocity-time curve for that interval. Displacement = Area under the v-t curve.
For Car A, the area under the curve represents the displacement and is bounded by curve A, the velocity axis, and the lines t=0 and t=t₁.
For Car B, the area under the curve represents the displacement and is bounded by curve B, the velocity axis, and the lines t=0 and t=t₁.
The total area bounded by both curves, the horizontal axis, and the vertical lines at t=0 and t=t₁ forms a rectangle with height (v₂ - v₁) and width t₁, giving a total area of (v₂ - v₁) × t₁.
The rectangle is divided by the two curves (A and B), and the sum of the areas under the two curves equals the area of the rectangle: Area under curve A + Area under curve B = (v₂ - v₁) × t₁.
Given the symmetry shown in the graph, the area under curve A equals the area under curve B, which is (v₂ - v₁) × t₁ ÷ 2.
The displacements of cars A and B are the same during the period from t=0 to t=t₁ because the areas under their respective velocity-time curves are equal.
